text: Data keeps growing within the game of football,
and we have more college data than we've ever had.
We have wearable technology data that we never had.
We have computer vision data that we've never had.
Bringing that new data in means that we have
to re-update models, improve our learning and our knowledge.
And because everything is organized the way that it is,
we're able to accessibly do that in a much easier way.
By utilizing the AWS infrastructure, we've been able to
make this entire process more streamlined and a lot more mature.
So we're able to bring in these data sets and these data sources
directly from the company's APIs.
We're able to combine them, write queries against them,
create unique data sets that can be used for analysis.
And then on the back end of that, rather than sharing the analysis
in manual reports that people were depending on us for creating,
we're able to build web applications that put the data
and the outcomes, the outputs, right in the end usersâ€™ hands.
This is the most important period of time: it's player acquisition.
We've got free agency. We've got the draft.

It's really useful for our
scouting staff to know about
when we start going out on pro days

and collecting data
on potential draft picks,

because that allows us to
identify players that might otherwise
be missed but have unique athletic profiles that could be useful.

They could be scouting a player
anywhere across the country, log in,
and be able to access information about players, about teams,
about the player's health on our own team,
about player evaluations.
We're able to access that data immediately,
run those models on the back end immediately,
and spit those models out to a web app or a big dashboard
that actually sits in the front of the room.
So as we go to another player, we change the dashboard
and they can see that stat line, how we forecast the player,
what we think about this player and all that information
is directly curbside for them.
And setting up our backend infrastructure through AWS,
it's allowed us to ingest data and build analysis that
builds communication across those departments
as they look at similar types of data.
And we can spin it in different ways, unique to their questions,
and that communication
helps to hopefully drive better decision making.
